description: This workshop is for people who would like to explore artistic expression through the use of a programming language, or people who are interested in creative forms of data visualization. By the end of this workshop you will have created data-driven, generative art using Python. In this workshop, you will learn how to: use Processing in Python mode, identify APIs that provide useful data for creating generative art, and create a unique work of art by calling a weather API and defining an original generative art algorithm. Please bring a laptop to participate in the hands-on activities.

description:
One of the nicest things about Python community is the availability of mentors willing to help you. Various mentors have helped me navigate the open source community and help advanced my skills. I realized finding a mentor is not as easy as it seems, and it takes a lot of courage to reach out in the first place. And then, there is impostor syndrome, where one may feel like they don’t deserve the help.
In this talk, I will provide advice about working with a mentor.
Asking for help is not a failure. 


This talk is for members of Python and open source community who are looking for a mentor, and needing clues as to how to find a good mentor. Those who are hesitant to ask for help may get the encouragement to reach out. Current mentors will gain insight about what their mentees are going through.

* Introduction

* Marketing tactics for developers

  * Very brief overview of paid advertising

* Resources

* Conclusion

description:
The purpose of this talk is to introduce the audience to a sampling of the various components that go into an **Inernet-of-Things (IoT)** solution. We delve into an example that uses an embedded microprossor board containing the **ESP8266 WiFi** chipset running **MicroPython**, which is interfaced to a few sensors. We also introduce the audience to the use of the **MQTT** protocol and the use of a **MQTT Message Broker**.

The example demonstrates the connection of a **remote embedded processor to a local WiFi access point**, connection to an **MQTT Message Broker** through an **MQTT client** library, **capture of data from connected sensors** and the subsequent **upload of the measured data** to a server using the MQTT messaging protocol.
bio:
I am a hobbyist dabbling in the world of IoT. Over the past 6 months I have become fascinated with the Espressif ESP8266 and ESP32 family of WiFi chipsets. In my day job I provide corporations with enterprise solutions while in my spare time I indulge in minor hacking with microprocessor boards such as the Arduino, Raspberry Pi, Adafruit Feather, Sparkfun Thing, etc. Python has made working with these devices much more easier than having to learn the deep intricasies of the C/C++ tool chains otherwise needed.

The Internet-of-Things (IoT) has piqued my interest and I have been diving deep into the various components of such solutions.
name: George Koodarappally
title: A Beginners Guide to IoT Using ESP8266 and MicroPython

description:
If you've ever found unreadable PEP8-compliant code and wondered how to fix it, this talk is for you.

Long-lived code must be maintainable and readability is a prerequisite of maintainability.  It's easier to identify unreadable code than it is to create readable code.

Let's talk about how to create readable code.

During this talk we'll discuss:

- whitespace
- self-documenting code
- modularity
- expectation management

We'll conclude this talk with a checklist of questions you can use to make your own code more readable.
name: Trey Hunner
title: Readability Counts

description:
​There is an ongoing mantra within the developer community: that there are far more jobs available then programmers to fill them. Which should be an indication as to the wonderful potential for both business and those learning to code. Yet what often follows such statements are not words of joy but rather a list of frustrations related to the difficulty in finding and retaining enough skilled developers to fill these positions. 
The challenge is not in the number of newbies entering the field but the number who leave because they are not able to bridge the divide between bootcamps, online tutorials, books, videos, etc. to an employable developer who is able to contribute to the team. 
Kim has years of experience working with learners of various ages in helping them develop the skills they needed to be successful at whatever their chosen goal. She understands that for businesses to be successful, they must develop more effective and efficient ways of recruiting and retaining developers in order to meet organizational benchmarks. 
The developer community is a overwhelmingly generous one and a well designed mentoring or apprenticeship program could be one answer that business leaders and newbies are looking for.

- The business costs associated with corporate hiring managers inability to recruit and retain skilled workers to fill current and future entry-level positions are increasing (Queen, 2014). 
- 89 percent of organizational leaders stated that they are having difficulties filling open positions, which is causing them to either turn down orders, miss key deliverable deadlines or hire individuals from outside of the United States (Aho, 2015). 

Aho, K. (2015). The robotics industry: creating jobs, closing the skills gap. Techniques, (7), 22. Retrieved from https://www.acteonline.org/techniques/#.VpMcQq6rR0s

Queen, J. (2014). Hire power: to close the skills gap, states are teaming up with industries that need, but can't find, qualified workers. State Legislatures, (8), 16. Retrieved from http://www.ncsl.org/bookstore/state-legislatures-magazine.aspx
bio: ​Kim has years of experience working with learners of all ages, skill level, and abilities and she would like to offer what she knows about successful mentorship to her new community. Kim is the author of the "Tech Talk For Non-Techies" blog and is currently pursuing a Doctors of Business Administration - Technology Entrepreneurship. Kim is working on her passion project JrDevMentoring.com and has been consulting with various bootcamps since speaking at ScotlandJS 2016.
name: Kim Crayton
title: ​ Overcoming the Challenges of Mentoring

description:
The world is swimming in articles and books about Django and Django ORM itself. All this sources cover only basic use cases of Django ORM comparing to real world examples.
This talk is dedicated to the proposition to crash test Django ORM 80% of functionalities in 20% of the time.  Also I’m going to show the important features and capabilities of Django ORM compare to most of SQL features. Traditionally, ORM is presented in a “bottom-up” fashion, but I would like to propose approach, on the other hand, is “top-down”. We begin by identifying a rather short list of standard questions, or precisely types of questions, that are often asked of relations databases. We then show how these standard questions are posted in Django ORM, introducing and motivating the use of its capabilities and features as they become relevant.

description:
Development began in late 2012, but the problem really has been a thorn in our side for quite some time.  Penetration testers, red teamers, and offensive security professionals have been frustrated with antivirus for as long as we can remember.  Professional malware and exploit kit developers can bypass antivirus solutions with ease, so why can’t the white hat industry?  Well, it turns out we can, but there’s never been an open source option.  This is where Veil-Evasion steps in.

I, along with others, began researching different methods to evade antivirus, and found a python solution!  One thing that we noticed, is that no matter how malicious we made our tool, antivirus continued to ensure us that we were safe :).  After nearly one year of having open sourced our solution Veil-Evasion, our python-based malware had its first signature.  Close to thirty minutes later, this “malware signature” was trivially bypassed by Veil-Evasion for the continued generation of “safe” executables.

I plan on elaborating on how a single python script has transformed into a framework for generating antivirus evading executables. This is the story all about how individuals have been playing the cat and mouse game with the multi-million dollar antivirus industry, and haven’t been batted around yet.  One day the antivirus industry will utilize better detection methods for malware, but today is not that day.
bio: Christopher Truncer (@ChrisTruncer) is a sys admin turned red teamer with Mandiant, and a previous Blackhat Instructor. He is a co-founder and current developer of the Veil-Framework, a project aimed to bridge the gap between advanced red team and penetration testing toolsets. Chris also works on a variety of other open-source projects such as EyeWitness, Just-Metadata, and more. Chris began developing toolsets that are not only designed for the offensive community, but can enhance the defensive community's ability to defend their network as well.
name: Chris Truncer
title: Bringing Down The House - How One Python Script Ruled Over Antivirus

description:
This talk covers two tools for securing your users' data while developing a public API.
(1) getting a free HTTPS cert with LetsEncrypt's Python CLI
(2) the Paillier cryptosystem - develop APIs which can work on users' encrypted data, without accessing the unencrypted numbers. As an example, you could develop an exchange-rate API without sharing transaction details.

This talk will take a look at misconceptions across the board, some experiences, both positive and negative, people have had crossing barriers to new languages, and show some of the benefits thinking of one's self as a coder and not a "Ruby coder" or a "PHP dev" can have on being a better problem solver.

description:
As our small team grew into a medium sized engineering team, we found a number of challenges in our dev process.  In particular keeping track of what Trello tickets had been deployed (and when) became cumbersome for both developers and product managers.  Using Python scripts integrated with our Ansible integration, we were able to streamline our dev and product process through a few simple steps:
1.  tag cards that had been deployed
2.  create clearly labeled columns in Trello
3. post deploy notes in Slack
4. make a few other helpful improvements to our dev process. 

In this talk, I will go through our Python scripts and various API resources needed to create tooling around dev process. I will walk through using Python in Jupyter notebooks, locally, and on production devOps boxes hosted on AWS.

description:
Celery is an asynchronous task queue for Python. This talk will start with a brief introduction to Celery, how and when to use it in your project and a discussion of common scenarios and pitfalls of using celery in Production.

We will explore typical configurations of Celery in a production environment, how to keep Celery running happily and how to quickly diagnose failures.

The talk will consist of:
* Quick introduction to distributed task queues
* Configuring Celery for Production - general principals
* Adding asynchronous tasks to your code
* Storing and Retrieving Task results
* Monitoring & Testing
* Scaling Celery

description:
You’re smart, educated, and you’ve been working in this industry for years. You’ve created amazing open-source packages and great documentation. But all that flies out the window if what you write about your project isn’t being read.

“But it’s comprehensive! It has all the info that I would need!” you may reply.

The problem is not writing for people like you; it’s writing and creating documentation that anyone can read, understand, and get excited about. This is true for projects aimed at beginners, but it goes double for projects and writing aimed at intermediate/expert programmers. Your projects will benefit when you write something that everyone can understand and would want to read. More readers = more users = perhaps more contributors!

Outline:


* Introduction

   * About me and my experience.

   * With Hello Web App, my book series.

   * Running workshops and working with beginners.

   * Being a relative newcomer myself.

* The basics of friendly and welcoming writing

   * Why make the effort to be friendly and welcoming?

   * Better installation and usage instructions.

   * “Dumbing things down” without making them dumb.

   * Formality vs. informality.

* The basics of writing clearly

   * Cutting down your content.

   * Better headlines.

   * Making your content readable.

* Conclusion

* Questions

description:
New open source communities are born everyday. Some of them are meant to last long and some others aren't. There's a moment in every community when it needs to outgrow itself, expand its limits and aim way higher than ever. This is no necessarily related to its goals but the ecosystem it needs to stay alive.

Once a community has gone beyond its limits, the community members, consumers and leaders will have to keep up with its pace. How do we help it to remain sane? How do we keep our goals on track while allowing for further growth? How do we allow it to keep expanding without further damaging the community?

These are all questions we ask ourselves everyday in the OpenStack community and that we've managed to work on without killing ourselves on the way.

description:
I'm all about efficiency. Not just code execution efficiency, but also regarding my work tools, and my usage of them.

Having been an avid programmer and Linux user for several years now, and being obsessed with my workflow efficiency, I've amassed a pretty good understanding of how to improve productivity when it comes to writing code.
From small but powerful configurations for my text editor that took me weeks to find to some not-so-well-known tools, I'm always thinking about how I can tweak my environment and workflow to perfection.
Have you ever considered how many keys you hit during the day? And how can you go about minimizing that and train your muscle memory to make you more efficient?
And what about that thing you're not even noticing you're spending so much time on, and that you could improve on?

This talk will feature some practical advice using my tools of choice (mostly Linux, tmux & Vim), and where applicable, all examples will be adapted to Python development.
The goal is not to try to tell you what to use, though. Instead, I want to show you a different perspective, and hopefully make you more aware of your efficiency, and of how you can improve it.

description:
Staring at my coworkers, already knowing the inevitability of the situation, my eyes roll as the argument ensues yet again: “I told you I can write that code twice as fast, in half as many lines and they’ll be cleaner and more readable than yours will ever be! Python is awesome!” — said the one guy.
“Whatever you say, you’ll never be able to make a UI that’s half as good as this. It won’t look pretty and no one will want to use it!” — replied the other — “Probably can’t even make it run on Windows” — he mumbled to himself while walking away.

Some years ago this was a regular exchange between coworkers, and while they were mostly messing around, there was still an element of truth to it. Regardless of its capabilities, Python was mostly known as a “scripting” language — not really for graphical interfaces — and the world was still looking for a native OS feel in their GUI applications, which was not really accessible from Python without a lot of work.

Where are we now with user interfaces? How does this picture look like for Python? Where do we want to be? How can we best leverage the technologies of today? Where should we improve? What can we do so that Python is ready for the future of user interfaces? These are some of the questions that I'd like to start answering.
bio: Born in the Dominican Republic, I went to college at UPR Mayagüez for Computer Engineering and spent the next 14 years in some sort of test engineering role, where I've developed hardware and software tooling to help enable cross-geographical organizations to plan, execute, manage and monitor their operations as needed. I've worked with many programming languages developing all sorts of applications from low-level software that interacts directly with firmware, to infrastructure services applications, all the way up to higher level business apps. Throughout my journeys, Python has been - and continues to be - my language of choice.

description:

The goal of the talk is to get you up-and-running exploring your own investment ideas with Python by the end of the hour.
